pullRequest.body:
We define `PointedCone` as `Submodule ùïú‚â•0 E`.
Most of this code is copied from the `ConvexCone` file. 

The main reason for this type synonym is to be able to work with direct sums/products of cones (which are now just direct sums/products of submodules).

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

nodes.body:
> I think there's a lot of deduplication to be had by defining `PointedCone` to be an abbreviation for `Submodule` over the nonnegative scalars.

I was thinking about this but wasn't comfortable because it felt like a very drastic change from the definition of ConvexCone.

But I'll go ahead and do this as I prefer the algebraic definition myself.

Thanks!

Hi @YaelDillies , I've rewritten pointed cones using submodules.

This resulting in getting rid of an entire section about modules and replacing it with a single constructor for constructing a submodule from a pointed cone. I also had to modify the maps section slightly.

> > The main reason for constructing this new structure is to define direct sums/products of cone.
> 
> Those should rather be direct sums/products of submodules, right?

Yeah, now the direct sums/products should just be that of submodules.
Can you update the PR description then?

bors d+

Thanks for your patience on this one!
I think there's a lot of deduplication to be had by defining `PointedCone` to be an abbreviation for `Submodule` over the nonnegative scalars.

> The main reason for constructing this new structure is to define direct sums/products of cone. 

Those should rather be direct sums/products of submodules, right?

All looks good now, thank you! Looking forward to the next PR üòÑ 

maintainer merge

bors d+

Thanks for your patience on this one!
We think that your plurals is wrongs.
That still doesn't read right ü§î

I think you're looking at an older commit. This is what it's changed to now
`We define pointed cone as a convex cone which contains 0. ` 

I'll definitely update this when I redefine pointed cone as a `Submodule`. Will try to mimic the doc style in other files.
Yeah that's what I was reading. I would expect "We define a pointed cone as a cone..." or "We define pointed cones as cones..." but yours was a weird mix of both.

Either 
```suggestion
to use the module API to work with convex cones.
```
or
```suggestion
to use the `Module` API to work with convex cones.
```

```suggestion
theorem coe_injective : Function.Injective ((‚Üë) : PointedCone ùïú E ‚Üí ConvexCone ùïú E) := fun S T h => by
```

```suggestion
  coe_injective' := coe_injective.comp SetLike.coe_injective
```
works I think
This one's not working for some reason.

```suggestion
/-- A pointed cone is a convex cone that contains `0`. -/
```
You're missing `@[simp, norm_cast] lemma coe_map`.

```suggestion
Iff.rfl
```
so that it's usable by `dsimp`.

```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
```

```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
```

```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
```

```suggestion
def coe_hom : S ‚Üí+ E where
```
or
```suggestion
def coe_addMonoidHom : S ‚Üí+ E where
```

```suggestion
def toSubmoduleEquiv : PointedCone ùïú E ‚âÉ Submodule { c : ùïú // 0 ‚â§ c } E where
```
This makes me wonder: Can't you take this as the definition of `PointedCone` and reconstruct the API from there?
I like this better as well. I'll redefine `PointedCone` and clean up the code.
I misread this originally: I thought you meant there is an instance `Module {x : k // 0 <= x} (PointedCone k E)`. Can you clarify the module doc?
This is indeed what it means! The instance comes from being a `Submodule` although it is never explicitly defined.
Hopefully this will get much clearer once I redefine `PointedCone`.

```suggestion
A *pointed cone* is defined to be a convex cone which contains `0`. This is a bundled version of
```
Can this not be made a general instance?

Can you move this instance to a much earlier file and make sure it's called `Nonneg.instModule`? If you can't find any sensible file, feel free to start writing `Algebra.Order.Nonneg.Smul` or `Algebra.Order.Nonneg.Module`.

Btw you're missing some lemmas:
```
@[simp, norm_cast] lemma Nonneg.coe_smul (a : ùïú‚â•0) (x : E) : (a : ùïú) ‚Ä¢ x = a ‚Ä¢ x := rfl
@[simp, norm_cast] lemma Nonneg.mk_smul (a) (ha) (x : E) : (‚ü®a, ha‚ü© : ùïú‚â•0) ‚Ä¢ x = a ‚Ä¢ x := rfl
```
+ some scalar tower instances
Done.
Accident?
huh, I don't even understand what happened here! I'll try to revert this.
It still seems to be there. You might have to revert a few commits.
I'm very sorry about this. Not sure what is causing this.
Maybe move that to an earlier `Nonneg` file?

```suggestion

```
Why not just `open scoped Nonneg`?

I tried this but I keep getting the error 

```lean
unknown constant 'ùïú‚úù'
```
Then your notation is broken :(. What error do you get when you remove the `set_option`?

Without the `set_option` the error is 

```lean
unknown identifier 'ùïú' at quotation precheck; you can use `set_option quotPrecheck false` to disable this check.
```

I'll just remove this notation completely. I think there should be a notation introduced much earlier in the `Nonneg.Ring` files.

Ah yeah, your notation is bogus. You're making `ùïú‚â•0` be notation for `{a : Œ± // 0 ‚â§ a}` for *any* `Œ±`. My na√Øve attempt `
notation Œ± "‚â•0" => {a : Œ± // 0 ‚â§ a}` fails too, so I'm asking @kmill.

You need `local notation` (and be sure to drop `scoped`). In principle having a notation with a local `variable` is fine, but it only works within the section it's defined. Be aware that at the moment you should not use `ùïú‚â•0` in further `variable` commands (this issue is tracked [here](https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/issues/2535)).

I know `notation3` supports local variables, though allowing it to pretty print would need #6833.

If `local notation` doesn't work, try
```lean
local notation3 (prettyPrint := false) "ùïú‚â•0" => { c : ùïú // 0 ‚â§ c }
```
Once #6833 is in you should be able to delete `(prettyPrint := false)`.
Thanks! I'll try it out

Isn't that already inferred?
```suggestion
instance : Coe (PointedCone ùïú E) (ConvexCone ùïú E) := by infer_instance
```
No, this is not working :(
Wait sorry, of course it is not.
Same for this
This one does work.
I meant you should remove it üòÖ

```suggestion
def _root_.ConvexCone.toSubmodule (S : ConvexCone ùïú E) (hS : S.Pointed) : Submodule ùïú‚â•0 E where
```
maybe?

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma mem_ofConvexCone : x ‚àà ofConvexCone s ‚Üî x ‚àà s := Iff.rfl
@[simp] lemma coe_ofConvexCone : (ofConvexCone s : Set E) = s := rfl
```

```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
theorem coe_dual (S : PointedCone ‚Ñù E) : ‚Üë(dual S) = (S : Set E).innerDualCone :=
```

Spaces around parentheses were eagerly added by mathport, but we don't want them.
```suggestion
instance instModule : Module {c : ùïú // 0 ‚â§ c} E :=
```
Could we also have the `OrderedSMul` instance?

```suggestion
/-- A module over an ordered semiring is also a module over just the non-negative scalars. -/
```

Can you move that before the `abbrev` and use it there? Also we do not usually put spaces inside curly brackets.
```suggestion
-- TODO: remove `prettyPrint := false` once #6833 is merged
local notation3 (prettyPrint := false) "ùïú‚â•0" => {c : ùïú // 0 ‚â§ c}
```

This doesn't work for some reason. I get the error 

```lean 
failed to synthesize instance
  LE ùïú‚úù
```

I used to get the same error when I was trying out `notation` instead of `notation3`
What does not work? Using notation in the `abbrev` or removing the spaces?
Using notation in abbrev.
I've removed the spaces.
Would you mind moving the notation earlier, regardless of whether you can use it?
Aha, the reason it doesn't work is because you're introducing a new `ùïú` in the definition.
I've tried all sorts of permutations but `abbrev` doesn't seem to like `notation`. I'm fixing the duplication of type that you mention. Still the same issue.

I'd tend to `open Function` to shorten this to
```suggestion
theorem coe_injective : Injective ((‚Üë) : PointedCone ùïú E ‚Üí ConvexCone ùïú E) :=
```

```suggestion
def _root_.ConvexCone.toSubmodule {S : ConvexCone ùïú E} (hS : S.Pointed) : PointedCone ùïú E where
```

Does this complain?
```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
```

Yeah 

```lean 
norm_cast: badly shaped lemma, rhs can't start with coe
  ‚ÜëS
```
Do you really need that `let`?

If I just try `f` I get 

```lean 
/-
  failed to synthesize instance
    SemilinearMapClass (E ‚Üí‚Çó[ùïú] F) ?m.64229 E F
  -/
```
Ok. Managed to get rid of it with a coercion.

```suggestion
@[simp, norm_cast]
```

This does the same thing btw.
```suggestion
abbrev PointedCone (ùïú E) [OrderedSemiring ùïú] [AddCommMonoid E] [Module ùïú E] :=
```
Does this form a diamond for `E = ùïú‚â•0`?
Ah no, I think it's safe.

Now that we're in Lean 4 where `coe` doesn't exist, this should have an auxiliary definition,
```suggestion
/-- Every pointed cone is a convex cone. -/
@[coe]
def toConvexCone (S : PointedCone ùïú E) : ConvexCone ùïú E where
    carrier := S
    smul_mem' c hc _ hx := S.smul_mem ‚ü®c, le_of_lt hc‚ü© hx
    add_mem' _ hx _ hy := S.add_mem hx h

instance : Coe (PointedCone ùïú E) (ConvexCone ùïú E) where
  coe := toConvexCone 
```

```suggestion
  add_mem' hx hy := S.add_mem hx hy
```

```suggestion
  add_mem' := S.add_mem
```
maybe even?
The second one doesn't work. Lean is having trouble figuring out the implicit variables.

Shouldn't this be:
```suggestion
    (S.toPointedCone hS : ConvexCone E) = S :=
```
Thanks! This also let's us use `norm_cast`.
Can you add `toConvexCone_map` too?
While writing this I discovered that `ConvexCone.map` was unnecessarily requiring `k` to be a `LinearOrderedField` while only `OrderedSemiring` is sufficient.
It would be nice to have a `CanLift` instance in terms of this definition.

Can you add the `SMulCommClass` instances too?


Also, this should be stated more generally, something like
```suggestion
instance instIsScalarTower [IsScalarTower ùïú ùïú' E] : IsScalarTower ùïú‚â•0 ùïú' E :=
  SMul.comp.isScalarTower ‚ÜëNonneg.coeRingHom
```
I don't expect you to need to modify the proof.
I ended up creating a few intermediate instances.

I think this (and any other lemmas about `‚Üë` that refer to `ConvexCone`) should be called
```suggestion
theorem toConvexCone_positive : ‚Üë(positive ùïú E) = ConvexCone.positive ùïú E :=
```
so that `coe_` can be reserved for the statements about coercion to a set.
Is this true by `rfl`?

I suspect this might behave better as
```suggestion
instance canLift : CanLift (ConvexCone ùïú E) (PointedCone ùïú E) (‚Üë) ConvexCone.Pointed where
```
or similar

For reference (and to create a github cross-link)

* #6833

Thanks!

Those should rather be direct sums/products of submodules, right?
